text: the first thing we should do is post on Discourse that people with private packages should not publish UUIDs of those packages because it opens them up to this attack

elements.text: the first thing we should do is post on Discourse that people with private packages should not publish UUIDs of those packages because it opens them up to this attack

text: To the extent that it's possible. If you distribute your software outside your own organization it might be difficult not to expose UUIDs and obviously impossible if the registry itself is public.

elements.text: To the extent that it's possible. If you distribute your software outside your own organization it might be difficult not to expose UUIDs and obviously impossible if the registry itself is public.

text: Yeah, for the HolyLabRegistry, the registry is public (<https://github.com/HolyLab/HolyLabRegistry|https://github.com/HolyLab/HolyLabRegistry>) so all the UUIDs are already leaked.

text: I had not, thanks <@U7THT3TM3>! Annoying because when we do transition packages from closed to open (e.g., when we publish papers) we'd have to transfer their registration from a private to a public registry.

elements.text: ! Annoying because when we do transition packages from closed to open (e.g., when we publish papers) we'd have to transfer their registration from a private to a public registry.
